blocks.text: Operating system vulnerabilities affect core components responsible for managing memory, processes, and hardware. When exploited, they can allow attackers to bypass security controls and gain full administrative access.

Privilege escalation flaws are especially dangerous because they allow attackers who already have limited access to elevate their permissions. Kernel-level vulnerabilities may provide complete control over the system.

Because the operating system underpins all applications, OS vulnerabilities often have wide-reaching consequences. Malware that gains kernel-level access can disable security tools, hide from detection, and persist across reboots.
Timely patching, system hardening, and minimizing unnecessary services are critical to reducing exposure to OS-level vulnerabilities.
